This needs 2021.2
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/47162
Can you rebase this and probably https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43170/13 and pick up 2021.2

@Gunnar
Updated it in ibm-openbmc/bmcweb

Because this patch rely on https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/37045
and we dont want to rebase it.
Done
The set will be a separate commit?
Looks like we never broke out PATCH into its own commit?

Looking at the history:
I see in patch set 2 where Gunnar created this comment the PATCH for these properties was not implemented. 

Patch set 3 then added the PATCH implementation.

I don't interpret Gunnar's comment as requiring a different commit for adding the PATCH.

Is it acceptable for the GET and PATCH to both be in this same commit?

> Is it acceptable for the GET and PATCH to both be in this same commit?

I am okay with it. This comment is 3 years old at this point.
It is good if we check for nullptr.
Done
Done
How does the client enable this?
I think we need "ControlMode": "Enabled" to enable / disable
Done
Do we need an allowable values here?
My understanding is that when ControlMode is disabled, that is, when PowerCapEnable is false, SetPoint is null, so the allowable values are not set here.
But of this ControlMode enum we only allow 2 of them, I think we need an allowable values
I understand what you mean,I will do it.

No mapper call? 
Is this the way we had this before? 
What if this interface doesn't exist at this object / path?
I will do it.
Done

But what if the client just enabled it? 
Would it simplify the logic if we did allow this? 
Does the backend allow this? What is the harm in allowing setting the point before enabling?

When PowerCapEnable is false, the backend is allowed to modify the value of PowerCap.
The reason for writing this way is to consider that when ControlMode is disabled, SetPoint is null, and when the value of PowerCap is modified at this time, SetPoint is always null, which cannot reflect that the value of PowerCap has been changed.

I think this falls into Redfish's "A client might want to turn off the water and still adjust the plumbing". See https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/44644. 
Can we just remove this check?
OK,I will do it.

Not an internal error the client just set a Value not supported..
How about PropertyValueNotInList ?
I will do it.
Done
Can you add an allowable values for this?
Done

I don't see an allowable values like 
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/ed3982131dcef2b499da36e674d2d21b2289ef29/redfish-core/lib/managers.hpp#L241
I misunderstood it before, now it has been added.

We shouldn't see a InternalError when we set 
'{ "PowerLimitWatts": {"ControlMode": "badValue"}}'
Done

Can we use a proper variable name here? 
powerCap ?
Done
Can we use a proper variable name here as well?
Done
Why does this need to be in the if / else ?
Done
Can you use a proper variable name ? If this is still needed? I don't understand why..
Done
Huh? Why do we still need this call?
Done
Done
Done

Doesn't a "GetAll" save us a call?

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/f201ffb46cec98eba672a06d06951117e3829013/redfish-core/lib/processor.hpp#L353
Done

I am confused why we have mapper only for the Get.. 
I would think we want mapper for both the Get and Set
Done

Need to do a check for  serviceName[0].first.empty()?
Or connectName.empty() ?
Under the premise that the serviceName has a value, it may happen that the connectionName is empty?

Patch Set 13 changed this to skip the GetSubTree and get the properties directly using the hard-coded path. So the need for this check went away with that change.

Due to other review comments I'm adding back the GetSubTree() call to avoid hard-coding the D-Bus path. In adding this back I've added this check as well.
Done

Done
Don't you need a return? Also I liked this check above like you had it in patchset 9

Patch set 11 added the return.

I've looked at the checks in setPowerControlMode() in Patch set 9 but I'm not seeing any difference with what is in Patch set 10.

I'm not sure what the second part of this comment is referencing. Can you clarify what checks to change? Maybe it was already addressed?
I think you are good. "Patch set 11 added the return."
So PowerLimitWatts is a new object in EnvironemntMetrics v1_1_0 which came out in Redfish version 2021.2?
I've reworded the commit message to reference the relevant Redfish schema and the version where PowerLimitWatts was added.
Done
I don't see AllowableMax/AllowableMin implemented
These were implemented as part of Patch set 13.
Done
Is this the same as the Old Power Control Schema?
Yes, I've updated the commit message to indicate this.
Done
This should be done
Patch set 13 added the privilege check of redfish::privileges::patchEnvironmentMetrics for the PATCH of these properties.
Done
FYI. I'm going to start working on addressing the code review comments of this commit and the other unmerged commits for this same topic.
Same here.  Why is this path hardcoded?  Also, why is a power cap under a specific host.  It's a chassis property, right?  Something like a GPU likely has a power cap.

I've removed the hard-coded path.

I asked Chris Cain about the D-Bus path for the PowerCapEnable property. His explanation: This is a system power cap (for the entire system).  If power exceeds this cap, all the processors in the system will get throttled to bring the power down.
? Why is this path hardcoded?   This will make ALL chassis set the power cap for this one path?

I've removed the hardcoded path.

See comment https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/47300/comment/ef848f61_2974b1e0/ about the relation between power_cap and chassis.

Please set both of these in one place.  Don't set it, then later on in the function (like 326) override it.

Also, behavior wise, if PowerCapEnable doesn't exist, we just assume it's enabled?  It looks like PowerCapEnable has been in the schema for 7 years now.  We can just assume it exists (change powerCapEnable  to not be a pointer).
Done
Why are these coming from the Cap interface, and not the CapLimits interface?  Do we need to deprecate one or the other?

The work to implement Control.Power.CapLimits has been marked WIP for almost two years.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openpower-occ-control/+/58066

I asked Chris Cain about the state of its implementation and it is not actively being worked at this time. 

For bmcweb to support these properties in the near term it needs to use the current implementation. If Control.Power.CapLimits is later implemented the bmcweb implementation would need to be modified. That should also trigger the deprecation of the Control.Power.Cap interface.
Lets just return 204, like we do elsewhere on PATCH.  keeping these aligned seems difficult.

I'm not clear on what this change this comment is requesting.

Here for the GET path if any of the PowerLimitWatts properties are not retrieved from the D-Bus that equivalent property in the Json response won't be filled in. Is that not the behavior that is desired?
Should it be an ERROR here or at the caller?

getPowerLimitsPath() is called for both the GET and PATCH routes.

I've restructured to handle the errors at the caller.

- The PATCH callers will check if subtree was empty or not to decide which error to return.
- The GET caller will just skip if empty in order to avoid causing the entire EnvironmentMetrics request from failing. (Is that correct?)
Acknowledged
Yeah, we shouldn't need a .clear() here
Good idea. I've made this change and agree it makes the error handling cleaner.
Acknowledged
Should it be an ERROR here or at the caller?
I've moved the error handling to the callers who will handle differently based on whether they are a GET or PATCH. I've left the BMCWEB_LOG_DEBUG() in this function to help with debugging.
Acknowledged

On the Patch, we can't just ignore it if there is an error.

if subtree is empty, that is a 4xx on the Patch 
if subtree.size() > 1, 500 error on the Patch and the Get

I've kept the function but modified its footprint and how the errors are handled.

I've corrected here to return propertyValueNotInList() if there was an empty subtree. Any other failure is treated as an internal error.
Acknowledged
Would this be `ec1.value()`, or `ec1` (to show both)?
Changed to ec1 as that seems to be the common case. Looked for other similar cases and changed those as well.
Acknowledged
include array, include string_view
Done
Should this be `ERROR`?
Good catch! Fixed this one and looked and corrected others with same problem in this file.
Acknowledged
This is a PATCH, need an error here if we aren't able to do it.
I've corrected here to return propertyValueNotInList() if there was an empty subtree. Any other failure is treated as an internal error.
Done
Would this be `ec1.value()`, or `ec1` (to show both)?
Yes, changed to ec1 which seems to be the common usage.
Acknowledged
Should we add `ERROR` before this?
Good catch! Added it.
Acknowledged

The current code seems assuming that it is Disabled if the parameter does not exist? Is this the correct assumption?

Should this be like this to check the existence of paramter?

```
 bool *powerCapEnable = nullptr;
```
OR

```
 std::optional<bool> powerCapEnable;
```

An earlier patch set had this as an optional pointer. It was pointed out that this has been here for 7+ years and should just assume it exists.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/47300/comment/c26af4a8_2d77e004/
Acknowledged
Would this be `ERROR`?
Yes, good catch! Corrected.
Acknowledged

I think this can be simplified by using `setDbusProperty()`.

```
sdbusplus::message::object_path path(pathAndService.first);
setDbusProperty(asyncResp,  pathAndService.second, path, 
                "xyz.openbmc_project.Control.Power.Cap", 
                "PowerCapEnable", "PowerLimitWatts", powerCapEnable);
```

Good point! I've changed both of the setProperty() calls here to use the utility function.

(I didn't have to create the object_path variable as the call passing the string does the cast itself.)
Done
I think it is good now

This is called on the PATCH? 
EBADR should still be an error, I think just a propertyValueNotInList
Good point this is for PATCH, I've added the error handling.
this is a PATCH so EBADR is still an error, just a client error
Good point, I've added the error handling.
Can we return here and then `else` can be removed?
I added. I also added a return below when the size is checked for the serviceMap.
`return` here.
Good catch, thank you! I've added it.
`return` here to avoid `messages::propertyValueNotInList()` for this case
Yes, good catch! I've added it.
Wouldn't it be an ERROR, and `internalError()`?

I didn't think so. This is in the call-chain from handleEnvironmentMetricsGet(). Which is getting the data for multiple objects.

If we don't have a path or service to this object for PowerLimitWatts on the GET then we just don't include the object in the array.

I thought it would be treated differently from an actual error from the D-Bus call which is handled above.

Agree?
Acknowledged
It looks good to me

We have this functionality in the GUI https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/blob/918526f20c16a05c261a56814657942a707323dd/src/store/modules/ResourceManagement/PowerControlStore.js#L13

Would be good to get this in so the GUI can move over to the new models. This appears to match how the old code was done in power.hpp
